title: erdogan wins turkeys presidential election unofficial results
story: Speaking on national television, he said: "The nation has entrusted to me the responsibility of the presidency and the executive duty."I hope nobody will try to cast a shadow on the results and harm democracy in order to hide their own failure."But it was a bittersweet night for Mr Erdogan because his AK party lost its majority in parliament, meaning that he no longer has total control of all areas of Turkish political life. A unusual coalition of nationalist, Islamist and secularist parties teamed up to successfully break his hold.Mr Erdogan will become the longest serving and most powerful Turkish leader since Kemal Attaturk, the founder of modern day Turkey. He has ambitions to become the most influential too.Mr Erdogan has jailed thousands of opponents since an attempted coup in 2016. There were reports of voter fraud and intimidation in some Kurdish areas in the southeast of the country.Allegations of ballot stuffing were also doing the rounds on social media."Armed people are openly wandering the streets of Suruc, threatening the election atmosphere," said one opposition spokesman.

title: eu leaders hold frank and open talks at emergency migration summit
story: At the meeting, Italy came up with a 10-point plan and said the burden of migrants had to be shared by all member countries.The plan, presented by Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, sought more EU support to help the Libyan coast guard patrol its coasts more effectively to stop migrant boats.The plan argues that existing European asylum rules are obsolete.The Italian proposal says other European countries must create welcome centres for asylum seekers so the burden is shared.

title: liam fox prepared to accept a longer brexit transition period
story: Government sources told The Times that Mrs May is set to ask the EU for another two years of transition - extending the period before full Brexit to seven years after the public voted for it.Mr Fox told Sky News: "What I wanted was that we were outside of the single market and the customs union and outside the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice."That's where I think we're going to end up. If we do it slightly more slowly in order to minimise any disruption that's fine by me."He said an extension to the Article 50 period - which is set at two years by EU statute - would not be "politically acceptable" to him, but he refused to be drawn on whether he would resign if it did happen.But he said he would not have an issue with an extension to the transition period, which the government has said will end on 31 December, 2020, as there may be reasons why it is inevitable.Mr Fox added: "To keep Britain in the European Union would not be politically acceptable. It would not be acceptable to me."If the transition period had to be extended for technical reasons... if, for example, one other country was unable to ratify the agreement or we didn't have technical means in place and we already had the withdrawal agreement and the future economic partnership already agreed, I wouldn't have a major problem with that, as long as it was very time limited and there was a unilateral mechanism for Britain to pull out of it if we thought that we were being kept in the European Union against our will." Extending the transition period has the potential to reduce the possibility the UK would crash out of the EU without a deal - something some major companies have said would be unacceptable.

title: overjoyed brigitte nielsen 54 welcomes fifth child
story: The Danish-born actress announced her fifth pregnancy on Instagram and Twitter in late May, showing her baby bump in a light-coloured dress.She also shared another bump picture, writing, "Happy time positive vibes."And a few days ago the couple were photographed in what appeared to be a selfie, with a message to Dessi: "You'll be a great papa."Nielsen previously spoke in August 2008 about wanting to have more children.She told Hello! magazine: "The children have kept me going. After I do Playboy, we want to try IVF. It's asking a lot, but if it's possible, it would make our package complete."

title: swiss players investigated over double headed eagle goal celebrations at world cup
story: FIFA outlaws all political messages or symbols in stadiums and the two players could be banned for up to two games if they are found to have breached their rules.Many people in the former Serbian province of Kosovo, which has an ethnic Albanian majority, identify with the red and black flag.Shaqiri said his celebration in the Kaliningrad stadium was "just emotion" but added he was not allowed to talk about politics.The Serbian football association reportedly complained to FIFA before the game about the Kosovo flag on one of Shaqiri's boots. The Swiss flag is on his other shoe.

title: why panama is partying like theyve won the cup
story: Panama scored once in the 78th minute - their first-ever World Cup goal - and they're partying like they've walked away with the trophy."How d'you like the way we're celebrating?" I was asked by one fan waving a camera in my face. Terrific. This is carnival, a Panamian fiesta, the greatest show on earth.They're not going to let the matter of almost total annihilation on the pitch get to them. England fans are outnumbered by the Panamians but there are more here than there were in Volgograd.And what a game to watch - Gareth Southgate's young and approachable team now firmly anchored in the hearts of the nation. They looked in control, they looked like they were enjoying themselves, it looked like they had a plan.Long may it last.And, once again, almost in chorus, every fan will tell you what a warm, enthusiastic, astonishing welcome they've had from the Russians."We cannot thank the Russians enough," said Paul Conroy from Liverpool."Boris Johnson doesn't know what he's talking about." In contrast to other nations here, England fans have tried for the main to keep a low profile.Lots say they now regret not bringing their families or encouraging more of their friends to travel.They say the government did little more than scaremonger ahead of the games. I ask Mr Conroy if he has a message for Russia's president, given his enthusiasm for the country's people."Politics is a different thing," he says."This is a festival of football, for ordinary people." This World Cup is going terrifically well for England, for the Russian national team and therefore by default for the Russian president too.

title: jamie oliver hails ban energy
story: NewsJamie Oliver hails ban on energy drinks as government brings in plans to cut childhood obesityHealth Secretary Jeremy Hunt included the ban in a raft of new proposals including a 9pm watershed on junk food adverts&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud20:51, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJamie Oliver thanked Mirror readers for getting behind the Can It! campaign after a plan to ban the sale of energy drinks to kids was announced. Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt included the ban in a raft of new proposals to cut childhood obesity, including a 9pm watershed on junk food adverts. Jamie, 42, who has campaigned alongside us for a ban, said: “I really think this was driven by the strong support of the Mirror and its readers. These drinks are not fit for kids and are affecting not only them negatively but also classrooms around the country. This is a great move for better child health but also a great move to support our teachers to help kids learn. We need to keep supporting this in the consultation.”  The ban on selling caffeine and sugar-laden drinks, such as Red Bull, to under-16s is included in Mr Hunt’s draft policy which aims to halve childhood obesity by 2030. Mr Hunt was appalled at figures showing energy drinks were being consumed by 25% of six to nine-year-olds. His proposals will be subject to consultation before a final decision. Mr Hunt said: “It is near impossible to shield children from exposure to unhealthy foods. Parents are asking for help. It’s our job to give them power to make healthier choices. The cost of obesity – on individual lives and our NHS – is too great to ignore.”

title: labour vows bring huge defence
story: NewsLabour vows to bring huge defence contracts back under state control in major new policyShadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith will reveal the party’s plan to scrap deals with outsourcing giants - as she insisted Trident would be kept&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor00:01, 25 JUN 2018Updated00:03, 25 JUN 2018NewsShadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith will reveal the party’s plan (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBumper Ministry of Defence contracts will be brought back in-house by a Labour government, military experts will be told today. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith will reveal the party’s plan to scrap deals with outsourcing giants in a bid to raise standards. The frontbencher will point to a series of disasters involving multimillion-pound contracts between MoD the private sector after the Tories hived off deals as they tried to save cash. Ms Griffith, who has held her post since October 2016, has said Labour would back sending more troops to Afghanistan to continue the fight against the Taliban. She told the BBC’s Andrew Marr the party would not not reverse its decision to keep Britain’s Trident nuclear deterrent despite Jeremy Corbyn’s well-publicised opposition to the programme.  The Welsh MP stressed it was party policy to support the nuclear deterrent, saying this was not the time to be “descaling” it. She said: “I think if you look at the world today it’s a more uncertain place than it’s ever been. I think if you look at the way the United States is not stepping up to the mark, I don’t think this is the right time to be getting rid of our nuclear deterrent. Vowing an immediate review of existing contracts and a ban on awarding new deals, Ms Griffith will tell the Royal United Services Institute think tank today: “The next Labour government will get to grips with outsourcing at the MoD. “Upon taking office, we will carry out a root and branch review of significant service contracts that have been outsourced by the Department. “And where they are not delivering, where they are failing our personnel and their families, or failing to provide value for money to British taxpayers, we will have no hesitation in bringing these contracts back in-house.  “And we will call an immediate halt to the significant contracts that are currently being considered for outsourcing, with Labour introducing a clear presumption in favour of public contracts being delivered by the public sector.” The pledge comes after the Government’s decision to hand a contract for the Defence Fire and Rescue Service to Capita, despite the company achieving the highest possible risk rating in an internal MoD assessment. The firm was recently stripped of its contract to run MoD military estates, while its deal to run for recruitment to the Army has been plagued by problems, leaving the Service 5,000 troops below strength. Meanwhile, Service families have repeatedly complained of broken boilers, rattling windows and mouldy walls in homes where a private firm is responsible for upkeep.

title: 11 best spots uk watch
story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:07, 23 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting. 1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland  A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer. Bike need replacing?   If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90). And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear. Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:  Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables  2. The Eden Project, Cornwall   Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby.  Get there in style on the Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike , &pound300. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination. Camping out?   Planning to camp? Be sure you book in advance as you won't want to be without a pitch. Croft Farm Holiday Park is just a mile from the Eden Project and three miles from the beach. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail. Consider taking a Halfords Vis A Vis 4 Person Tent with you, which is currently reduced to just &pound60, (was &pound150, save &pound90). The simple tunnel design is easy to pitch in approximately 20 minutes. With two separate bedrooms and a living area, it's perfect for families or groups of friends. For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.  3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales  The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm. Why not try..   The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. This bike is adept at riding in comfort on roads but really excels when you want to get off the beaten track.   4. White Nancy, Cheshire   Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week. Need to drive?  Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first. A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.  If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road. 5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland  There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. The views of Edinburgh from the castle are amazing, and a great place to watch the end of the day roll around. Sunset here will take place at 9:58pm. 6. Hampstead Heath, London  The scenery on Hampstead Heath always pleases the eye. This amazing part of London has views of every landmark you could hope for and it's a wonderful place to watch the sun go down. This will happen at around 9:18pm in the capital.   7. Osborne House, Isle of Wight   The home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert is quite a sight to see. Accessible by bike (and ferry, if you're not an island resident), it's the ideal place to see during the day before you settle down somewhere to watch the sunset. If you're up for the cycle, Shanklin Chine on the west of the island is well worth an evening visit.  Do it with ease - and classic style - on the Pendleton Somerby Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound750. With added electrically powered pedal assistance, it delivers 40 - 50 miles of range through a rear hub motor with speed sensor. This extra power is enough to guarantee effortless rides, taking the strain out of hills and making moving off from a standstill much easier. If you prefer, this bike is also available in a non electric version and in a range of colours - we love the mint green ! The sunset starts at 9:18pm near Osborne House and 9:17pm in Shanklin Chine.  8. Ness Point, Lowestoft    Ness Point is the UK's most easterly point. This makes it a great place to ride to on National Cycle Route 1. Make yourself comfortable on the Halfords XL Waterproof Picnic Blanket , &pound10 (half price) and watch the waves crash in as the sun goes down. Sunset is 9:16 at the UK's most easterly point.  9. Blackpool Pleasure Beach, Lancashire   With plenty of places to cycle in the area you could have an amazing day out in Blackpool. Start with a ride to the Pleasure Beach, and have some fun with the kids (or without them!) on the roller coasters. When all that's done you can have fish and chips while the sun sets on another day. The sun will go set at around 9:43 in Blackpool.  10. Cotswolds, England  Spread over six counties there's a lot to see in the Cotswolds. Consider taking a ride through the picturesque Castle Combe to take in the amazing houses and the stunning market square. The sun sets on this beautiful village at 9:26pm  Find your way by car - and beat the traffic   If you're driving to somewhere new then why not add a sat nav to your car? The TomTom GO 6200 , &pound270, (was &pound339.99, save &pound69.99) adds real-time traffic information to the navigational benefits of a sat nav (smartphone required for this feature).   11. Giant's Causeway, Northern Ireland

story: NewsBrave mum battered by her boyfriend shares horrific pictures of her injuries caused by ex-boyfriend's brutal abuseJade wants readers to see the horrific images in the hope it would encourage other people suffering domestic violence to come forward about their abuse&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLuke TraynorPippa Allen-Kinross13:42, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA courageous mum-of-three has shared horrific photographs of the injuries caused by the brutal abuse of her thug ex-boyfriend.  Jade Brett-Moore shared the appalling photographs to encourage other victims of domestic violence come forward about the abuse they are suffering, after her ex Daniel McLean was jailed for four years for the countless attacks against her.  The pictures shared by the 23-year-old show how her whole body was subjected to vicious attacks, with McLean even using a deliberately-sharpened end of a metal broom stick to cut at her legs.  She told the Liverpool Echo she was overwhelmed and thankful that McLean had been sentenced.  It was like living with absolute torture and I'm just so glad to be away from it now, she said. It was basically near enough every day for months and months on end. There's been so many occasions that I couldn't name them all. She said she wanted other people going through domestic abuse to know they can get the support to free themselves from the violent situation.  I'd say to those out there that right now, whatever place and whatever you're in, you might see it as being impossible to break free, and while you're in it you just think there's no way of ever getting out of it and you're stuck in that. But no, you're not. You can break out of it and you can get help and support. It's important that you must break free of it. No one deserves to go through what they do. McLean once told his partner: I'm going to rape you and throw you in the lake. After one vicious attack, he threatened her: It'll be me or you that'll be dead tonight. The brute also threatened to have her gang raped, punched her in the stomach when she was pregnant, said he would throw acid in her face and once used shards from a mirror he had smashed to cut her. Jade, writing after he was sent down last week, said: So this[McLean] is my babies' father, sadly, who most of you will already know because of his pathetic reputation. Who not only put me through five years, on and off, of hell, but who knew I'd gone through hell with a previous partner who was convicted and justice was served. Really, I should have listened to my family back then and real friends who warned me. But he was adamant he had changed, so I gave it a last shot. I was his victim of abuse and torture.  Not only did I suffer from months of soft tissue damage, fractured ribs, mental torture for things that happened to me which were not my fault - I was slashed and whipped continuously, [suffered] cuts from numerous different objects to my temple, head and body, covered all my legs in black bruising, from top to bottom,.. I couldn't eat, I was losing weight rapidly and he knew I had an eating disorder... McLean, of Southport, was jailed last week for four years after admitting two charges of assault and the breach of a restraining order. A new restraining order has been imposed, stopped McLean from contacting Jade for 10 years. A judge described him as a danger to the public and described much of the evidence as harrowing and examples of his obsessive and manipulative behaviour. Jade added: He wouldn't let me shower on my own or go the toilet on my own, in case I was sneaking someone else in. I wasn't allowed out anywhere I couldn't wear make-up or nice clothes because I was a 'slag'. He called me anorexic, then said I was fat, always brought me down on how I looked, and that I was unattractive which made me feel so insecure, told me no-one would ever want me because of my life... title: british families ditch meals together
story: NewsBritish families ditch meals together in favour of time in front of the tellyGatherings around the table are disappearing as the box takes over as the focal point, research found&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJosh Layton17:36, 24 JUN 2018NewsFamilies are more likely to watch TV together (Image: Getty Images)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain is turning into a ‘Gogglebox’ nation as families abandon traditional mealtimes in favour of watching television. Gatherings around the table are disappearing as the box takes over as the focal point, according to research firm Opinium. The number of families eating an evening meal together every day has dropped from 57% in 2014 to just 48% at present, the study found. Meanwhile, the number watching television together on a daily basis, typified by the Channel 4 show and its armchair critics, has risen from 49% to 54% over the same period. Nutrionists and experts in childhood obesity say the figures ring alarm bells in light of studies showing that families who share mealtimes are more likely to eat healthy food. Children who joined round the table were found to consume 125g more fruit and vegetables than those who didn’t, according to one study by Leeds University in 2012. Young people included in communal meals are also believed to perform better in schools and have superior fitness.

story: NewsCelebrity portraits are first class as artist makes pictures out of 3,000 old train ticketsBritish artist, Ed Chapman spent 280 hours putting the pictures together&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRob Knight15:51, 24 JUN 2018Updated15:55, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCheck out this first class artwork – made completely out of old train tickets. British artist, Ed Chapman, 47, created the portraits of well-known East Midlanders including Sir David Attenborough, former-Doctor Who Matt Smith and comic Alan Carr using over 3,000 discarded tickets. The 10 pieces took a whopping 280 hours to put together in total. Other famous names created include fashion designer Dame Vivienne Westwood, comedian Jennifer Saunders, and the late Sir John Hurt CBE, star of The Elephant Man. East Midland Trains commissioned the artwork to raise awareness of their new mobile tickets – which can be stored on your smartphone and save on paper.  Artist Ed Chapman said: “It was quite a surreal moment seeing all of these famous faces come to life in front of me from what originally started as a pile of discarded paper tickets. “The colourings on train tickets are unique and distinct, that once I started playing around with some they actually lent themselves perfectly to mosaics. “Not only are the images of famous faces from the East Midlands, but the craft materials themselves have each travelled on a different journey across the region, each with its own story from station to station. “Hopefully it will inspire a few people to cut down on their paper ticket use – or even create their own artworks.”  The artist from Darwen, Lancashire has previously produced a portrait of Jimi Hendrix made entirely from guitar picks, a mosaic of David Beckham from old pennies and even recreated tennis-star Andy Murray in carpet stains. Jake Kelly, managing director, East Midlands Trains, said: “What Ed has done with a few thousand old and unused paper tickets is pretty remarkable. “As well as bring a smile to a few faces, we want to use these artworks to raise awareness about the benefits of using mobile tickets. “In addition to saving time and hassle at the station, there’s a clear environmental benefit to adopting digital tickets.” “These tickets represent just one hour’s worth of paper tickets sold across our network, with over 28,000,000 tickets printed across the whole year. “By the end of 2018, we aim to have fully rolled out mobile tickets across the entire network and so significantly cut down on this number.”

story: NewsDerelict chalet transformed into luxury holiday apartment worth £850,000The once unloved Cornish chalet is now an opulent holiday home complete with a hot tub and heated outdoor shower&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMiles O'LearyPippa Allen-Kinross16:04, 24 JUN 2018NewsImagine having breakfast with this view (Image: Unique Home Stays www.uniquehomestays)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA once derelict chalet on the Cornish coastline is now worth a small fortune after two property moguls transformed it into a stunning holiday home. Husband and wife team Katherine and Adam Wooler fell in love with the location of the abandoned chalet off Whitsand Bay, and rebuilt it from the bottom up after negotiating with Cornwall Council to overturn strict planning laws.  Called Seaglass , it comes complete with a natural spa, including a hot tub and heated outdoor shower with a beautiful view of the sea.   It also boasts posh skylights, bi-fold doors that look out onto the ocean, Cornwall Live reports.   The Wooler's rent it and last year alone raked in &pound123,000 from holiday makers - who have even been known to touch down in a private helicopter. But they've decided the time is now right to sell the freehold of the posh apartment as the family enjoys a new start in New Zealand. It's available to buy right now - but you'll need a cool &pound850,000 in your back pocket.  Katherine said: The chalet had to be a similar size to the previous one bedroom chalet, but it was the size of the plot that really attracted us and the sense of isolation from the other chalets dotted along the cliff. It was initially our intention to live there but with the arrival of our baby, Ella-Rose, we decided to turn it into a holiday let. Having previously converted another chalet on the cliff into a holiday let, we were aware of the potential and growing demand in Whitsand Bay - also locally know as ‘Cornwall’s forgotten corner’. We purchased the property in July 2013 and had our first holiday let booking on New Years Eve 2013. We lived in Dorset during the build and were doing day round trips to Cornwall to oversee the build - with a six-month-old baby.

story: NewsJubilant England fan, 8, at centre of Fifa Twitter row gets the last laugh as he dances again during historic winMum Kathryn Conn hit the headlines last week when she posted a video of her son Alex dancing after Harry Kane put England in front against Tunisia&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Burke18:10, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young England fan has had an eventful week after a video of him celebrating fell foul of Fifa rules - but that didn't stop him enjoying the Three Lions' historic win today.  Mum Kathryn Conn hit the headlines last week when she posted a video of her son Alex dancing after Harry Kane put England in front against Tunisia.  Football's ruling body ordered the clip had to be taken off Twitter because it breached copyright rules - as viewers could just about see blurred action from the family's TV in the background. Kathryn labeled Fifa's actions petty. But the furore did not dampen Alex's enthusiasm for the game, with the schoolboy revelling in the attention.  The young Tottenham Hotspur fan was up and dancing today as his hero netted a hat-trick in a huge 6-1 win against Panama. Alex, from Weston-Super-Mare, watched England's win against Panama with his dad Steve and granddad Richard. Kathryn said: Every time Harry Kane scored he was very excited. Harry Kane is his idol, so he loves watching him score. He celebrates whenever England score, but it's really special whenever it's Kane who scores. And Alex had plenty to celebrate today, with three from Kane as well as two goals from John Stones and a stunner from Jesse Lingard.  It's the first time he and his friends have been old enough to know what's going in, said Kathryn. They're loving it. Since the dispute with Fifa was reported by  on Tuesday, Alex has been the centre of attention at school. He brought the article with him to school, he's really pleased with it, said Kathryn. He loves it, he's not a shy and retiring type of kid.  After her video of Alex's dance after Kane's 11th minute goal on Tuesday night was deleted, she said: It just seems really petty that they've got people monitoring the internet for things like this. It was a tiny little clip of a little boy celebrating something he really enjoyed.

title: mum threes torment after freak
story: NewsMum-of-three's torment after freak fall eight years ago leads to right leg amputationJulie Banwell, from Huddersfield, West Yorks., has endured crippling pain, taken up to 50 tablets every day and had physiotherapy since 2010&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly21:23, 24 JUN 2018Updated22:47, 24 JUN 2018NewsThe mum has had to have her right led amputated (Image: MEN Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum has spoken of her grief at having to have her right leg amputated — as a result of a freak fall off concrete steps eight YEARS ago.  Julie Banwell, 43, has spent the best part of a decade suffering debilitating pain, undergoing operations and taking up to 50 tablets a day. And the mother-of-three recently had her limb amputated, a move deemed by doctors the only option to end her crippling agony. Julie, of Newsome, near Huddersfield in West Yorks., stumbled on concrete steps as she took her then five-year-old son to school back in April 2010.  She had stitches in her knee but was diagnosed with the rare complex regional pain syndrome 18 months later. Julie, who works in education, said: I was an active mother and after a simple fall taking my little boy to school I haven’t been able to walk. There is no cure, just lots of treatments that do not help.  “I have been to every hospital across Yorkshire and had three knee operations, phyisotherapy, lidocaine infusions, acupuncture, steroid injections into the leg and even a spinal cord stimulator implant.  “I’ve had loads of blood clots and was having to take 50 tablets a day. I have had every painkiller you can think of.” But late last year, specialists at Huddersfield Royal Infirmary decided she must have the leg amputated.  Medics gave Julie only a 50/50 chance of the operation working but the surgery, carried out last week, appears to have been successful. I feel fantastic and I can’t thank everybody at the hospital enough for what they have done for me — they have been wonderful, Julie added. She is hoping the next step will be to have a prosthetic limb fitted. However, that too is beset with complications with Julie saying there is only a 50-50 chance of it happening. The mum continued: She added: “I’m very determined and would love to be able to walk again. I am just hoping that I can walk and have a life like other people.”

He said: “Abusing a nana is the ultimate no _ they are the heart of a family. “To hear her being called a dog and on the phone to her family, she’s worried — it is just sickening. “I was in total disbelief — I couldn’t believe the kids would do it. “I wish I was there to have sorted it. “As soon as I got the clip, I wanted to get it up there and find out who they are.”

story: NewsUK weather: Brits hit the beach for weekend heatwave ahead of 'hotter than Sahara' 33C sizzlerA ‘Spanish blowtorch’ heatwave will send the mercury soaring to 33C in what forecaster are predicting could be the first of up to EIGHT heatwaves this summer&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHenry Vaughan17:48, 24 JUN 2018Updated17:55, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain will be hotter than the Sahara desert this week as the country sizzles in the first of up to EIGHT heatwaves predicted this summer. A 10-day ‘Spanish blowtorch’ heatwave will send the mercury soaring to 33C from Wednesday - making it potentially the hottest day of the year so far. Temperatures will begin to rise from Tuesday after an already baking weekend saw millions flock to beaches and beer gardens up and down the country. Scores of people were out enjoying the sunshine as they watched England beat Panama 6-1 in the World Cup - and it looks like it'll be hotting up even further as England makes its way to the knock-out stages.  After a “marvellous” Midsummer’s Day at 27C, the Met Office forecast 30C by Tuesday and up to 33C on Wednesday and Thursday. Up to eight summer roasts are now predicted ahead – with each spell reaching at least 28C, according to AccuWeather, the world’s second biggest commercial forecaster. Britain will be matching Nouakchott, Mauritania on the edge of the Sahara Desert, by the middle of the week, where temperaturesare set to be around 31C on Wednesday. The hottest day so far this year came in April when a temperature of 29.1C was recorded in London.  Met Office forecaster Sophie Yeomans said: We would expect at some point this week to beat that. We are going to continue with the dry and sunny weather for most places. Top temperatures are going to be on the rise. We could see temperatures into the low 30s some time this week, possibly from Tuesday, but more likely from Wednesday. The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “A blowtorch feed of hot air will come from Spain.”

title: woman spotted doing handstand yoga
story: NewsWoman spotted doing handstand and yoga poses on the edge of crumbling cliffThe thrillseeker was criticised over the 'dangerous' moves, 200ft above jagged rocks in East Sussex&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNadeem Badshah17:14, 24 JUN 2018NewsTourists are warned that the cliffs could give way at any moment (Image: Wayne Spring / SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman put herself in danger doing a handstand on the edge of a crumbling cliff.  The daredevil left locals stunned after spending around 20 minutes performing a series of yoga poses 200ft above jagged rocks.  Despite giant cracks and signs warning that the chalk cliffs could give way at any moment, tourists are often spotted dangling over the edge of the Seaford Head cliff, in Seaford, East Sussex, to take selfies. Photographer Wayne Spring, 51, has seen scores of people gamble with death at the edge of the cliff and branded the woman’s behaviour “ridiculous”.  He said: I find myself questioning people's common sense quite a lot these days, but this was just another level. It was absolutely ridiculous - at the best of times, I can't understand why anybody would go anywhere near a crumbling cliff above a sheer drop. But this was something else - I couldn't believe my eyes when she did the headstand. The thrillseeker, who appears to be in her 30s, performed a series of poses at the edge of the cliff, including standing on one leg and the 'downward-facing dog' pose.  Snapper Wayne added: Yoga's meant to be relaxing, but I can tell you that it wasn't relaxing watching her. There was a crowd gathered around me at the time and people couldn't stop gasping. The woman was so firm with her poses, it just goes to show that she was totally oblivious to the danger she was in. The cliffs are so unstable, they could collapse at any time. Nobody's would ever be able to walk away from that drop, no matter how bendy they were.  The edge of the cliff is fractured with cracks, and every year along the iconic white cliffs, hundreds of tonnes of rocks fall onto the beach below. For years there have been calls to install security fences at the top of the cliff to prevent people falling off the sheer drop. Wayne added: If you fence it off you might spoil the area but you can't rely on people to use their common sense any more.  I don't want the natural environment to be spoilt by a few idiots but if a fence stops them then so be it. I think they're uninformed. If you are not from the area you will not know about the dangers but people just need to use their common sense. The South Downs National Park Authority, who maintain the Seven Sisters cliffs in Newhaven, East Sussex, have said fences are impractical because of erosion.  Seaford Head is along the same stretch of coastline as Beachy Head, one of the world's most notorious cliffs. Last week a five-year-old boy was found dead with his mother at Beachy Head.

story: NewsAston Martin driven by Sean Connery in Goldfinger 'is found in the Middle East' more than 20 years after it was stolenThe legendary car was stolen from an airport in Florida back in 1997&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly19:31, 24 JUN 2018Updated19:46, 24 JUN 2018NewsSean Connery portrayed James Bond in Goldfinger in 1964 (Image: Rex)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An iconic Aston Martin driven by Sean Connery's James Bond in Goldfinger has been found more than 20 years after it was stolen, detectives say. The vehicle, which was equipped with machine guns and tyre-bursting blades for Sean Connery's 007, could now be worth as much as &pound10 million.   Investigators from Art Recovery International, the insurance company to find the motor, would not disclose where exactly in the Middle East it may have been discovered. I have been given a specific tip, but we are working on it.  We want to reach out to [the] collector car community and [a] vast array of mechanics to let them know we are very serious about recovering it, Art Recovery International's chief executive Christopher Marinello told The Sunday  . title: mount everest climber who survived
story: NewsMount Everest climber who survived disaster that killed eight on peak died after falling down steps at homeCharlotte Fox spent her life travelling the world and scaling the world’s most beautiful, and dangerous, peaks&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByOliver Milne21:09, 24 JUN 2018NewsCharlotte Fox had spoken of doing one more climb in Nepal&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Charlotte Fox spent her 39th birthday on top of the world as she fulfilled her dream of climbing Mount Everest .  But hours after reaching the summit, the passionate mountaineer would find herself huddled in the foetal position, praying “death would come quickly”. She feared she would lose her life on the peak like so many others before her. Charlotte was made of sterner stuff than she thought, however, and after two days battling unimaginable conditions, she made it down the mountain. It was just one extraordinary day for a woman who spent her life travelling the world and scaling the world’s most beautiful, and dangerous, peaks. Tragically, she died last month after falling down steps outside her home, at the age of 61. By the time she took on the challenge of the world’s tallest mountain, Charlotte had already scaled all 53 of the 14,000ft peaks in western US state Colorado.  Her amazing survival story was immortalised in 2015 film Everest, starring Jake Gyllenhaal as Scott Fischer, a mountain guide, Keira Knightley, plus Amy Shindler as Charlotte. It was on May 10, 1996, now infamous in the mountaineering world, that Charlotte and 11 other climbers who had scaled the 29,029ft mountain were caught in a blizzard as they began their descent. The party were well aware that on Everest, rapidly changing weather isn’t just an inconvenience, it can be a death sentence. They found themselves caught in a whiteout, meaning it was impossible to tell which way they were going. Despite having rapidly depleting supplies of oxygen, used to help them breathe in the thin mountain air, the group had no option but to stop. The freezing winds caused Charlotte’s contact lenses to freeze on to her eyes. It was then, as the temperatures dropped to -50C and the winds roared at 70mph, that Charlotte curled up and waited for the end.  For two days the mountaineers battled to survive as snow battered them on the Southeast Ridge. Charlotte later recalled: “We waited for that warm fuzzy feeling that accompanied hypothermia and death.”  The storm eventually cleared, but eight of the men and women who had journeyed up the mountain would never come down again, including Fischer. It remains one of the worst disasters to happen on Everest. More than 375 people have died trying to climb it.  Writing in the American Alpine Journal, Charlotte described the relief that followed the storm’s passing. “Miraculously, the storm abated. Half-frozen we staggered to our feet and made an attempt to shuffle off. “My knees kept buckling and I couldn’t seem to make headway.” Just yards from the relative safety of her tent, Charlotte collapsed. It was Russian climber Anatoli Boukreev, who returned with an oxygen tank and dragged her back to camp, who saved her life. Later, people blamed the tragedy on the commercialisation of Everest. But for Charlotte, it was a dark episode during a life dedicated to mountaineering. During the summer before her ordeal she had tackled two other climbs in the Himalayas exceeding 26,300ft, Gasherbrum II and Cho Oyu. An only child born in North Carolina, Charlotte was a self-described “Southern belle” with a lifelong love of the outdoors and adventure. After graduating from university, she fell in love with the Rocky Mountains and made the state of Colorado her home. There, she became a talented waterskier and found a job in mountain rescue, living among the peaks that were her passion. She described herself as an “eternal fun hog”. Yet her disastrous descent from Everest was not the only time tragedy would strike in her life. In 1993 her boyfriend Mark Bebie was climbing in the Canadian Rockies when he died in an avalanche.  Heartbreak would strike again in 2004 when her husband of four years, Reese Martin III, died in a paragliding accident. But the loss of two loved ones did not leave Charlotte bitter. “I was never mad at Mark or Reese for dying in their pursuit of living,” she said. And despite multiple tragedies on the mountainside, Charlotte refused to give up her thrill-seeking. In the 22 years of her life which followed Everest, she scaled countless others but never returned to the mountain that almost took her life. But when asked to reflect on the tragedy which defined so much of her life, she said: “A bunch of people went climbing, each with his or her own reasons. There were no heroes or villains.” Her friends were distraught when on May 24 she was found dead at her home in Telluride, Colorado. She had celebrated her birthday just two weeks earlier. Charlotte died after falling down 77 hardwood steps outside her four-floor house. It had a lift but, despite sometimes being injured from her many climbs, she refused to use it as she wanted to stay fit on the stairs.
